item.title: Fast questions
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“RandQm, post:17, topic:430142”][quote author=t4 link=topic=532819.msg3896623#msg3896623 date=1327358412]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=532819.msg3896601#msg3896601 date=1327356956]

I prefer to use comma’s when I have variables that are relevant to one another.

    /* Following */
    private int npcfollowPlayer, playerFollowNpc, playerFollowPlayer;
    private boolean canFollow, isFollowing, needsFollowReset;

    /* Castle wars */
    private long gameTime, waitTime;
    private int castleWarsTickets, playersInGame, maxPlayers;
    private boolean inCastleWars, canJoin;

ew, non-functional booleans
[/quote]ew non functional language
[/quote]ew non functional brain

i hope you know i reported you for spamming!

ps:

/** The minimum and maximum */
int min, max;

DOUBLE COMMENTS HOW ABOUT THAT!

/**
credits / class intro
*/

/*
information
*/

Is how I use them
o.o[/quote]
incorrect!

Read full topic

@T41 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:7, topic:430142”]I prefer to use comma’s when I have variables that are relevant to one another.

[code=java]
/* Following */
private int npcfollowPlayer, playerFollowNpc, playerFollowPlayer;
private boolean canFollow, isFollowing, needsFollowReset;

/* Castle wars */
private long gameTime, waitTime;
private int castleWarsTickets, playersInGame, maxPlayers;
private boolean inCastleWars, canJoin;

[/code][/quote]

item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

As long as the two fields on one line are relevant in a way then I will use that and if not I will use the other style. Although it really doesn’t matter and you all are a bunch of pansies, most especially David.

item.title: Fast questions
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

‘Level’ and ‘size’ aren’t related, as it specifically says it’s to encourage commenting. Something like this would be fine:

int x_speed, y_speed; //The speeds at which the object is moving

as you get to the same result

Read full topic

item.title: Fast questions
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:9, topic:430142”][quote author=Pure Slay link=topic=532819.msg3895821#msg3895821 date=1327279160]

Best? Neither is better than the other. It depends on what you think is cleaner to read.

Through proper conventions, the first option is better.
[/quote]Not really, this is one of those conventions that is completely up to the writer. Other things like camel case etc, are pretty global, but stacking variables (in a readable fashion and in a way that makes sense) is almost always acceptable as well.[/quote]


It is a preferred way by conventions…

Read full topic

item.title: Fast questions
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote=“lemme_winks_, post:3, topic:430142”]you should only initialize a group of variables if they exist to define/contribute to one purpose or if they have something/are of relevance to each other – a little convention i follow for something like this.

however it all depends on what you want to do. nobody will force you to use one over the other. there is no speed factor or program efficiency advantage.[/quote]

Kej thanks both

Read full topic

item.title: Fast questions
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

you should only initialize a group of variables if they exist to define/contribute to one purpose or if they have something/are of relevance to each other – a little convention i follow for something like this.

however it all depends on what you want to do. nobody will force you to use one over the other. there is no speed factor or program efficiency advantage.

Read full topic

item.title: Fast questions
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

Can you do instead of:
int name;
int name2;

do
int name, name2;

I know you can, but what is the best?
